items.synopsis: The latest monthly consumer price indicator shows inflation eased sharply to 5.6 per cent over the 12 months to May, down from 6.8 per cent in April. Follow ourÂ live blog for the latest updates.

title.children: Future interest rate rises uncertain as inflation hits 13-month low of 5.6pc

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: More signs of the slowing economy. Property analysts CoreLogic says the rate of loss-making home sales rose over the first three months of the year as home prices decreased. However, the vast majority of homes still made a profit on their resale with a median nominal gain of $276,500 nationally. The median loss was $40,000. CoreLogic's Pain & Gain report found the percentage of dwellings that made a gain on their resale declined for the third quarter in a row to 92.3 per cent from a high of 94.2 per cent over the three months to May 2022. And an increasing number of homes sold had been owned for less than two years. Here's Eliza Owen, head of research at CoreLogic: âSuch short selling times that involve sellers incurring a loss may be considered unusual, because  hold periods typically increase during housing value downturns, as sellers try to avoid making a loss,â  Ms Owen says. âThe implication may be that some sellers are choosing to incur a loss from resale in order to avoid  particularly high mortgage repayments in the current rate-hiking environment." Profit making sales were highest in Hobart, Canberra and Adelaide. Darwin, Perth, Sydney and Melbourne saw an increase in loss making sales, with 10.7 per cent of sales in Sydney making a loss over the March quarter. Nearly 30 per cent of homes were sold at a loss in Darwin.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Fewer homes sold at a profit

children.content: More signs of the slowing economy.
Property analysts CoreLogic says the rate of loss-making home sales rose over the first three months of the year as home prices decreased.
However, the vast majority of homes still made a profit on their resale with a median nominal gain of $276,500 nationally.
Â
The median loss was $40,000.
Â
CoreLogic's Pain
Â
Gain report found the percentage of dwellings that made a gain on their resale declined for the third quarter in a row to 92.3 per cent from a high of 94.2 per cent over the three months to May 2022.
And an increasing number of homes sold had been owned for less than two years.
Here's Eliza Owen, head of research at CoreLogic:

âSuch short selling times that involve sellers incurring a loss may be considered unusual, because  hold periods typically increase during housing value downturns, as sellers try to avoid making a loss,â  Ms Owen says.
âThe implication may be that some sellers are choosing to incur a loss from resale in order to avoid  particularly high mortgage repayments in the current rate-hiking environment."
Profit making sales were highest in Hobart, Canberra and Adelaide.
Darwin, Perth, Sydney and Melbourne saw an increase in loss making sales, with 10.7 per cent of sales in Sydney making a loss over the March quarter.
Nearly 30 per cent of homes were sold at a loss in Darwin.

props.alt: Percentage of home sales made at a loss

children.content: Home sales
(CoreLogic)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here's some reaction from major business groups after annual inflation pulled back to 5.6 per cent in May. The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry says the retreat in inflation will bring some comfort to small business. ACCI chief of policy and advocacy David Alexander: âAfter experiencing 12 interest rate increases, declining consumer spending, and a surge in input costs, itâs good news for small businesses that inflation is returning to its downward trend." âMany small businesses are seeing their costs rise to the point where they have no choice but to increase their prices to maintain operations." Australian Industry Group chief executive Innes Willox says the drop in inflation is encouraging, but more rate hikes will likely be needed. "While encouraging for both households and businesses, and bearing in mind that the monthly ABS excludes some items, we are not there yet. " "Sticking on the path to target inflation will require continued restraint in price setting and wage negotiations by businesses, governments and employees." "With GDP growth of just 0.2 per cent in the March quarter, there is very little scope for further slowing without tipping the economy into contraction."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Business reaction to cooler inflation

children.content: Here's some reaction from major business groups after annual inflation pulled back to 5.6 per cent in May.
The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry says the retreat in inflation will bring some comfort to small business.
ACCI chief of policy and advocacy David Alexander:
âAfter experiencing 12 interest rate increases, declining consumer spending, and a surge in input costs, itâs good news for small businesses that inflation is returning to its downward trend."
âMany small businesses are seeing their costs rise to the point where they have no choice but to increase their prices to maintain operations."
Australian Industry Group chief executive Innes Willox says the drop in inflation is encouraging, but more rate hikes will likely be needed.
"While encouraging for both households and businesses, and bearing in mind that the monthly ABS excludes some items, we are not there yet. "
"Sticking on the path to target inflation will require continued restraint in price setting and wage negotiations by businesses, governments and employees."
"With GDP growth of just 0.2 per cent in the March quarter, there is very little scope for further slowing without tipping the economy into contraction."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Capital Economics thinks the slowdown in inflation is not fast enough to prevent further rate hikes by the RBA. And Marcel Thieliant, head of Asia Pacific at Capital Economics, believes the RBA's war on inflation could end in recession. "The sharp fall in inflation in May raises the risk that the Reserve Bank of Australia will not raise rates any further at the upcoming meeting in July, but we still think that mounting upside risks to inflation will prompt it to press ahead." "With the labour market still very tight, unit labour cost growth surging and the housing market bouncing bank with a vengeance, we suspect the Reserve Bank will press ahead with another rate hike next week." Capital Economics forecasts the official cash rate will peak at 4.85 per cent by September, and then the Reserve Bank will cut rates next year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: RBA to press on with rate rises

children.content: Capital Economics thinks the slowdown in inflation is not fast enough to prevent further rate hikes by the RBA.
And Marcel Thieliant, head of Asia Pacific at Capital Economics, believes the RBA's war on inflation could end in recession.

"The sharp fall in inflation in May raises the risk that the Reserve Bank of Australia will not raise rates any further at the upcoming meeting in July, but we still think that mounting upside risks to inflation will prompt it to press ahead."

"With the labour market still very tight, unit labour cost growth surging and the housing market bouncing bank with a vengeance, we suspect the Reserve Bank will press ahead with another rate hike next week."
Capital Economics forecasts the official cash rate will peak at 4.85 per cent by September, and then the Reserve Bank will cut rates next year.
